keyTakeAways: AI-generated voices are now indistinguishable from real human voices, especially when cloned from actual individuals.
Deepfake voice scams are rising globally, with over $547.2 million lost worldwide between January and June 2025.
AI voice cloning technology uses deep learning and natural language processing to mimic speech patterns, intonation, and even breathing sounds.
The public is increasingly trusting AI-generated voices as more authentic, with participants in research studies rating them as more trustworthy than real voices.

The use of AI deepfakes has expanded to include harmful applications such as creating sexual content and fake news, with industrialized production of AI-generated child sexual abuse material being a major global concern.
Governments are responding: the US banned AI-generated intimate images of people without consent, and Australia banned an app used to create deepfake nude images.
Despite risks, AI-generated voices offer positive applications, such as restoring speech for individuals who have lost the ability to speak.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A growing wave of AI voice scams has targeted wealthy Italian businessmen, with fraudsters using artificial intelligence to generate realistic voice clones of public figures like Defence Minister Guido Crosetto, falsely requesting money to rescue kidnapped journalists. The scam exploited the increasing realism of AI-generated voices—demonstrated in research by Queen Mary University of London—which found that AI voice clones are now perceived as equally real as human voices, and often more trustworthy. The fraud, which occurred just after Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni secured the release of journalist Cecilia Sala, led to a financial loss of at least $1 million when former Inter Milan owner Massimo Moratti transferred money. Global deepfake scams have surged, with over $547 million lost between January and June 2025, and AI-generated content is now being used to create sexually explicit material, prompting legal and policy responses in the US and Australia. While AI voice technology offers positive applications like restoring speech for people who have lost their voice, the rise of deepfakes poses serious threats to personal identity, financial security, and public trust.
title: AI now sounds more like us – should we be concerned?
